**The American Civil War (1861‑1865) did not erupt because of a single, isolated event.**  
It was the culmination of decades‑long political, economic, social, and cultural tensions that became increasingly irreconcilable after the United States expanded westward. Below is a synthesis of the major factors that historians identify, together with the evidence that supports each factor and a brief note on where scholarly debate still exists.

The 1857 Dred Scott decision (D.C. v. Sandford) intensified Northern outrage because it denied citizenship to all Black people. | The North increasingly framed the war as a fight over human liberty, while many Southerners framed it as a defense of a “positive good.” | Eric Foner, *Free Soil, Free Labor, Free Men* (1970) stresses the ideological clash over “free labor” vs. slave labor. |

**Scholarly consensus:**  
> *“Slavery was the central cause of the Civil War.”* – Nearly all modern historians (McPherson, Foner, Woodward) agree that slavery was the fundamental issue around which all other disputes revolved.

- Some 19th‑century historians (e.g., the “Lost Cause” writers) downplayed slavery, emphasizing “states’ rights.” Modern scholarship shows that the “right” in question was almost always the “right to maintain slavery.”

| **Tariff disputes** | The Tariff of 1828 (“Tariff of Abominations”) and the 1832 compromise sparked Southern calls for nullification.
